inactive-port-shutdown.description:
Enable/disable the laser auto shutdown function on the backup interface of the Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode.
After this function is enabled, the backup interface will be shut down. By default, the laser auto shutdown function is disabled.

preempt-enable.description:
Enable/disable delay switchback for the master member interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode. By default, this function is disabled. This function works together with revert delay time that can be configured only after this function is enabled.
After this function is enabled, the restored master interface automatically takes over traffic of the backup interface when the revert delay time expires.

preempt-delay-minutes.description:
Specify the delay interval (in minutes) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-seconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-milliseconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in million-seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

inactive-port-shutdown.description:
Enable/disable the laser auto shutdown function on the backup interface of the Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode.
After this function is enabled, the backup interface will be shut down. By default, the laser auto shutdown function is disabled.

preempt-enable.description:
Enable/disable delay switchback for the master member interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode. By default, this function is disabled. This function works together with revert delay time that can be configured only after this function is enabled.
After this function is enabled, the restored master interface automatically takes over traffic of the backup interface when the revert delay time expires.

preempt-delay-minutes.description:
Specify the delay interval (in minutes) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-seconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-milliseconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in million-seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

inactive-port-shutdown.description:
Enable/disable the laser auto shutdown function on the backup interface of the Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode.
After this function is enabled, the backup interface will be shut down. By default, the laser auto shutdown function is disabled.

preempt-enable.description:
Enable/disable delay switchback for the master member interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode. By default, this function is disabled. This function works together with revert delay time that can be configured only after this function is enabled.
After this function is enabled, the restored master interface automatically takes over traffic of the backup interface when the revert delay time expires.

preempt-delay-minutes.description:
Specify the delay interval (in minutes) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-seconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-milliseconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in million-seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

inactive-port-shutdown.description:
Enable/disable the laser auto shutdown function on the backup interface of the Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode.
After this function is enabled, the backup interface will be shut down. By default, the laser auto shutdown function is disabled.

preempt-enable.description:
Enable/disable delay switchback for the master member interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working in 1:1 master/backup mode. By default, this function is disabled. This function works together with revert delay time that can be configured only after this function is enabled.
After this function is enabled, the restored master interface automatically takes over traffic of the backup interface when the revert delay time expires.

preempt-delay-minutes.description:
Specify the delay interval (in minutes) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-seconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

preempt-delay-milliseconds.description:
Specify the delay interval (in million-seconds) at which the master interface of an Eth-Trunk interface working 1:1 master/backup mode switches back to the master state. Value 0 indicates that a master interface immediately switches back to the master state once it is restored. This time can be configured only after delay switchback is enabled.
After this time is configured, the restored master interface switches back to the master state only after the time expires, preventing frequent interface flappings and traffic loss.

strict-check.description: Enable/disable indicates URPF strict check. That is, a packet can pass the URPF check only when there is a matched entry in the forwarding table and the inbound interface is matched.

subnet-check.description: Enable/disable strict URPF check for common L2TP users, dual-stack L2TP users, L2TP leased line users, common PPPoE users, dual-stack PPPoE users, and PPPoE leased line users. If the parameter is not specified, strict URPF check is enabled only for common L2TP users, dual-stack L2TP users, common PPPoE users and dual-stack PPPoE users.

authentication-scheme.description: Configure authentication scheme. The default authentication scheme cannot be deleted.

first-authen-mode.description: Preferred authentication mode. The second, third, or fourth authentication mode is used only when the first authentication mode does not respond. The first authentication mode cannot be set to unavailable.

second-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the preference lower than the first authentication mode. The second authentication mode is used when the first authentication mode does not respond. If the setting of the second authentication mode is unavailable, the third and fourth authentication modes fail to be set.

third-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the preference lower than the first and second authentication modes. The third authentication mode is used when the first and second authentication modes do not respond. If the setting of the third authentication mode is unavailable, the fourth authentication mode fails to be set.

fourth-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the least preference. The fourth authentication mode is used when the first, second, and third authentication modes do not respond. If the setting of the fourth authentication mode is unavailable or the fourth authentication mode does not respond, the authentication fails.

authorization-scheme.description: Configure authorization scheme. The default authorization scheme cannot be deleted.

author-scheme-name.description: Name of an authorization scheme. The name uniquely identifies the authorization scheme and can be used in the domain.

first-author-mode.description: Preferred authorization mode. The second, third, or fourth authorization mode can be used only when the first authorization mode does not respond. The first authorization mode must be available.

second-author-mode.description: Authorization mode with the preference next to the first authorization mode. It is used when the first authorization mode does not respond. If the setting of the second authorization mode is unavailable, the third and fourth authorization modes fail to be set.

third-author-mode.description: Authorization mode with the preference next to the first and second authorization modes. It is used when the first and second authorization modes do not respond. If the setting of the third authorization mode is unavailable, the fourth authorization mode fails to be set.

fourth-author-mode.description: Authorization mode with the least preference. It is used when the first, second, and third authorization modes do not respond. If the setting of the fourth authorization mode is unavailable or the fourth authorization mode does not respond, the authorization fails.

no-lvl-first-cmd-author.description: Configures the first authorization mode for users of user group.

no-lvl-second-cmd-author.description: Configures the second authorization mode for users of user group.

no-response-policy.description: Configures a policy for a scenario where no responses are obtained during command line-based authorization.

no-response-times.description: Configures the number of times of failed authorization.

cmd-author-mode-type.description: Sorting method of cmd authorization mode.

accounting-scheme.description: Configure accounting scheme. The default accounting scheme cannot be deleted.

domain.description: Configure in a domain, users apply the same authentication/authorization scheme or server. The default domain cannot be deleted.

name.description: Name of a domain.

admin-level.description: The admin level of domain. If the command level adjustment function is disabled, the value of adminLevel ranges from 0 to 3. If the command level adjustment function is enabled, the value of adminLevel ranges from 0 to 15.

authen-scheme-name.description: Name of the authentication scheme used by the domain, it is not case sensitive. The default value varies according to domains. The default value is restored when the node is deleted.

author-scheme-name.description: Name of the authorization scheme used by the domain, it is not case sensitive. The default value varies according to domains. The default value is restored when the node is deleted.

acct-scheme-name.description: Name of the accounting scheme used by the domain, it is not case sensitive. The default value varies according to domains. The default value is restored when the node is deleted.

access-limit.description: Domain max access number. The default value is defined in the PAF file and is restored when the node is deleted.

radius-server-template.description: Name of the RADIUS server used by the domain, it is not case sensitive.

hwtacacs-server-template.description: Name of the HWTACACS server used by the domain, it is not case sensitive.

time-range-enable.description: Enable/disable the time range function used by a domain.

secondary-ip.description: Specifies the IP address of the secondary DNS server.

local-user-name-case-insensitive.description: Enable/disable the local user account is case-insensitive.

user-detect.description: Configure a user group in the domain.

retransmit-time.description: Indicates the number of times for detecting users by sending ARP packets.

ipv6.description: Enable/disable the user basic service type is IPv6.

ipv6-pd.description: Enable/disable the user basic service type is IPv6 PD.

cui.description: Configure users in a domain to apply to the RADIUS server for the CUI attribute when requesting to get online, and then adds the CUI attribute to the subsequent user accounting packets.

enable.description: Enable/disable users in a domain to apply to the RADIUS server for the CUI attribute when requesting to get online, and then adds the CUI attribute to the subsequent user accounting packets.

layer2-user-priority.description: The layer 2 users priority in which an IP address pool assigns IP addresses.

layer3-user-priority.description: The layer 3 users priority in which an IP address pool assigns IP addresses.

user-type.description: Specifies the type of a user.

accounting-exclude-vlan.description: Configure the router to exclude VLAN header length from packet length when collecting statistics about user packet bytes. This command applies to both IPv4 and IPv6 packet statistics.

annex.description: Configure string information to the left/right side of a domain name when the BRAS sends authentication and accounting request packets to the RADIUS server.

direction.description: Adds string information to the left or right side.

string.description: Specifies the string added to the DHCP option 125 attribute.

enable.description: Enable/disable MAC address authentication.

ip-pool-groups.description: List of the address pool group in a domain.

name.description: Specifies the name of an IP address pool.

framed-ip-urpf.description: Configure URPF when IP addresses are delivered by the RADIUS server.

enable.description: Enable/disable URPF when IP addresses are delivered by the radius server.

map-priority.description: Configure a device to preferentially assign MAP-T prefixes to users.

map-t-priority.description: Enable/disable MAP priority in a domain.

cut-time.description: Specifies the period after which the user connection is torn down.

rate.description: Specifies the amount of user traffic rate. If the user traffic rate is less than the amount, the user is considered idle.

zero-rate.description: Indicates that if the time when the user traffic rate is less than 1Kbyte/min reaches the idle-time value, the system will disconnect the idle user.

cut-flow-direction.description: Indicates that the parameter idle takes effect on the upstream or downstream traffic.

offline.description: Forces the users to go offline.

online.description: Allows the users to remain online.

url.description: Specifies the URL for forcible redirection.

stop-accounting.description: Indicates that a user sends an accounting-stop packet after the user is redirected because the quota of the user is used up.

enable.description: Indicates that a user sends real-time accounting packets after the quota of the user is used up.

any-address-release.description: Configure a device to forcibly log out a dual-stack user if the user releases any IP address.

offline.description: Enable/disable a device to forcibly log out a dual-stack user if the user releases any IP address.

public-ip-address-pool-usage-threshold.description: Configure threshold for public IP address pool usage in an AAA domain.

lower.description: Lower threshold for public IP address pool usage in an AAA domain.

upper.description: Upper threshold for public IP address pool usage in an AAA domain.

both-cgn.description: Enable/disable threshold in an AAA domain. The public IP address pool status is determined by the address pool usage in both CGN and non-CGN scenarios. By default, the public IP address pool status is safe in non-CGN scenarios.

user-volume-quato.description: Configure a user traffic volume quota to upstream or downstream traffic.

direction.description: User flow quota applying direction. By default, the user traffic volume quota applies to both upstream and downstream traffic.

accounting-start-delay.description: Configure a device to send an accounting-start packet about a dual-stack user after a specified delay.

ipv4-immediately.description: Enable/disable accounting immediately when the IPv4 stack is online.

delay-policy.description: Configure a device to send an accounting-start packet about a dual-stack user after a specified delay for user.

time.description: Specifies a delay in sending accounting-start packets.

user-type.description: User type for enable a device to send an accounting-start packet about a dual-stack user after a specified delay.

all.description: Enable a device to send an accounting-start packet about a dual-stack user after a specified delay all user type.
Delay process for All user type.

spec.description: Enable a device to send an accounting-start packet about a dual-stack user after a specified delay special user type.

assign-interface-id.description: Enable/disable allocates interface IDs during IPv6CP negotiation.

dhcpv6-wait-delay.description: Configure a timeout period for waiting for a DHCPv6 connection request from a PPPoE user on the.

wait-dhcpv6-time.description: Specifys the timeout period for waiting for a DHCPv6 connection request.

infinity.description: The infinite timeout period for waiting for a DHCPv6 connection request will not end the PPPv6 connection.

login-alarm-threshold.description: Configure alarm when manager login failed frequently.

user-name.description: Name of an access user, it is not case sensitive.

user-group-name.description: Specifies the name of a user group, it is not case sensitive.

realm-location.description: Specifies a position for a realm domain name.

real-name-delimiter.description: Specifies a realm name delimiter used to parse the user account. The value is a single character. It can be one of the following symbols: back-slant, /, :, <, >, |, @, %, '.

real-name-parse-direction.description: Specifies a parsing direction for the realm name.

roam-character.description: Specifies an identifier for a roaming user. The value is a single character. It can be one of the following symbols: back-slant, /, :, *, <, >, |.

authentication-scheme.description: Configure authentication scheme. The default authentication scheme cannot be deleted.

first-authen-mode.description: Preferred authentication mode. The second, third, or fourth authentication mode is used only when the first authentication mode does not respond. The first authentication mode cannot be set to unavailable.

second-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the preference lower than the first authentication mode. The second authentication mode is used when the first authentication mode does not respond. If the setting of the second authentication mode is unavailable, the third and fourth authentication modes fail to be set.

third-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the preference lower than the first and second authentication modes. The third authentication mode is used when the first and second authentication modes do not respond. If the setting of the third authentication mode is unavailable, the fourth authentication mode fails to be set.

fourth-authen-mode.description: Authentication mode with the least preference. The fourth authentication mode is used when the first, second, and third authentication modes do not respond. If the setting of the fourth authentication mode is unavailable or the fourth authentication mode does not respond, the authentication fails.

expire-days.description: Specifies an expiration period for a password. 0 indicates that a password is permanently valid.

prompt-days.description: Specifies a remaining validity period for a password.

change-check.description: Enable/disable mandatory password change when a password is used for the first time.

pwd-min-length.description: Specifies the minimum length for passwords configured for local users.

name.description: Name of a local user. The minimum length of a username is determined by user-name-min-len and security-policy. If security-policy is set to false and user-name-min-len is configured, the configuration takes effect. When security-policy is set to true, the minimum length of the username must be at least 6 characters. If user-name-min-len is configured and the user-name-min-len value is greater than 6 characters, the minimum length of the username is equal to the user-name-min-len value. If security-policy is set to false and user-name-min-len is not configured, the minimum length of the username is 1. If the username contains more than 32 characters, service-snmp cannot be set to true.

end-life-date.description: The end date of local user's life.

is-login-anytime.description: Enable/disable the flag of login anytime.

begin-login-day.description: The begin day of week for login.

end-login-day.description: The end day of week for login.

begin-login-time.description: The begin time of every login day. The begin-login-time must be five or more minutes earlier than the end-login-time.

end-login-time.description: The end time of every login day. The end-login-time must be five or more minutes later than the begin-login-time.

aging-in-days.description: The user will age if not online in the special days.

password-expire-in-days.description: The passowrd will expire in the special days.

group-name.description: Name of the user group where the user belongs, it must be an existing user group. The user inherits all the rights of the user group.

failed-times.description: When user continuous authen failed times reach the limit, the user is locked.

interval.description: Set a user lockout period (in minutes). If a user is locked due to consecutive authentication failures, the user is automatically unlocked after the set period expires. 0 indicats that the locked user is not automatically unlocked.

password-type.description: Set a password type, which can be cipher or irreversible-cipher. Cipher passwords are encrypted and generated using the reversible algorithm, while irreversible-cipher passwords are encrypted and generated using the irreversible algorithm.

password.description: Login password of a user, which is a string ranging from 1 to 128 characters for a unencrypted password and 32 to 268 characters for a encrypted password. The password can contain letters, numbers, and special characters. Chinese characters are not supported. The minimum length and complexity of a user password are restricted by pwd-min-length, security-policy, complexity-check, and forbidden-word. When security-policy is set to true, the minimum length of a password is 8 characters. In addition, complexity verification is enabled. The complexity requirements are as follows: (1) A password must contain digits, uppercase letters, lowercase letters, and special characters. Spaces and question marks are not supported. If the password is enclosed in quotation marks, spaces are allowed in the password. (2) The password cannot contain an account or the reverse string of an account. (3) The new password cannot be the same as any of the previous 10 passwords. (If the new password is the same as the current password, the new password is also considered as a history password. That is, the current password is included in the 10 history passwords.) This parameter takes effect when the password complexity check is enabled (complexity-check is set to true). If forbidden-word is configured, the password cannot contain forbidden words. If only the pwd-min-length value is set, the pwd-min-length setting takes effect. If the minimum length of a user password is set and the user security policy is enabled, the minimum length of a password cannot be less than 8 characters. If the minimum length of a password is set and the pwd-min-length value is greater than 8 characters, the minimum length of a password is determined by the pwd-min-length value.

level.description: Login level of a local user. If the command level adjustment function is disabled, the value of userLevel ranges from 0 to 3. If the command level adjustment function is enabled, the value of userLevel ranges from 0 to 15.

max-access-num.description: The local user max access number.

idle-cut-enable.description: Enable/disable configures the idle cut function for a local user.

begin-life-date.description: The begin date of local user's life.

is-aged.description: Whether the user is aged now.

is-locked.description: Whether the user is locked now.

left-lock-time.description: Left lock time of locked user.

is-terminal-locked.description: Whether the user is terminal locked now.

terminal-left-lock-time.description: Left lock time of terminal locked user.

is-pass-expired.description: Whether the password of this user name expires.

is-pass-changed.description: Whether the password of this user name is changed by the user.

alive-num.description: Online number of the local user.

name.description: Name of a local user. The minimum length of a username is determined by user-name-min-len and security-policy. If security-policy is set to false and user-name-min-len is configured, the configuration takes effect. When security-policy is set to true, the minimum length of the username must be at least 6 characters. If user-name-min-len is configured and the user-name-min-len value is greater than 6 characters, the minimum length of the username is equal to the user-name-min-len value. If security-policy is set to false and user-name-min-len is not configured, the minimum length of the username is 1. If the username contains more than 32 characters, service-snmp cannot be set to true.

end-life-date.description: The end date of local user's life.

is-login-anytime.description: Enable/disable the flag of login anytime.

begin-login-day.description: The begin day of week for login.

end-login-day.description: The end day of week for login.

begin-login-time.description: The begin time of every login day. The begin-login-time must be five or more minutes earlier than the end-login-time.

end-login-time.description: The end time of every login day. The end-login-time must be five or more minutes later than the begin-login-time.

aging-in-days.description: The user will age if not online in the special days.

password-expire-in-days.description: The passowrd will expire in the special days.

group-name.description: Name of the user group where the user belongs, it must be an existing user group. The user inherits all the rights of the user group.

failed-times.description: When user continuous authen failed times reach the limit, the user is locked.

interval.description: Set a user lockout period (in minutes). If a user is locked due to consecutive authentication failures, the user is automatically unlocked after the set period expires. 0 indicats that the locked user is not automatically unlocked.

password-type.description: Set a password type, which can be cipher or irreversible-cipher. Cipher passwords are encrypted and generated using the reversible algorithm, while irreversible-cipher passwords are encrypted and generated using the irreversible algorithm.

password.description: Login password of a user, which is a string ranging from 1 to 128 characters for a unencrypted password and 32 to 268 characters for a encrypted password. The password can contain letters, numbers, and special characters. Chinese characters are not supported. The minimum length and complexity of a user password are restricted by pwd-min-length, security-policy, complexity-check, and forbidden-word. When security-policy is set to true, the minimum length of a password is 8 characters. In addition, complexity verification is enabled. The complexity requirements are as follows: (1) A password must contain digits, uppercase letters, lowercase letters, and special characters. Spaces and question marks are not supported. If the password is enclosed in quotation marks, spaces are allowed in the password. (2) The password cannot contain an account or the reverse string of an account. (3) The new password cannot be the same as any of the previous 10 passwords. (If the new password is the same as the current password, the new password is also considered as a history password. That is, the current password is included in the 10 history passwords.) This parameter takes effect when the password complexity check is enabled (complexity-check is set to true). If forbidden-word is configured, the password cannot contain forbidden words. If only the pwd-min-length value is set, the pwd-min-length setting takes effect. If the minimum length of a user password is set and the user security policy is enabled, the minimum length of a password cannot be less than 8 characters. If the minimum length of a password is set and the pwd-min-length value is greater than 8 characters, the minimum length of a password is determined by the pwd-min-length value.

step.description: Indicates the step of the number of access users. Each time the number of access users on the router increases by the number specified by step value, the response delay is prolonged. The response delay for the access users within the step range is the same.

minimum.description: Indicates the minimum response delay for access users on the minimum-time specifies the minimum response delay.

maximum.description: Indicates the maximum response delay for access users on the maximum-time specifies the maximum response delay.

pppuser-offline-standardize.description: Configure a PPP user to preferentially get online when the PPP user and a DHCP user with the same MAC address attempt to get online.

enable.description: Enable/disable a PPP user to preferentially get online.

standard.description: Configure the type of standard format.

turkey.description: Indicates the format of Turkey version.

version20.description: Indicates the format of version 2.0, by default, the format of version 2.0 is adopted.

packet-strict-check.description: Configure the router to strictly check user packets of a specific type.

nd.description: Enable/disable the strict ND packets check function.

dhcpv6.description: Enable/disable the strict DHCPv6 packets check function.

ppp.description: Enable/disable the strict PPP packets check function.

l2tp.description: Enable/disable the strict L2TP packets check function.

dot1x.description: Enable/disable the strict dot1x packets check function.

protocol-statistics.description: Configure statistics about user protocol packets.

enable.description: Enable/disable flag.

ui-mode.description: Configure the command output in the user-defined format.

load-balance-enhance-algorithm.description: Configure the enhanced load balancing algorithm.

enable.description: Enable/disable the enhanced load balancing algorithm.

update-frequency.description: Specifies the frequency for triggering load balancing. It is the change of the number of users on an interface.

delay-time.description: Specifies a delay time for a load balancing group.

member-count.description: Number of member interfaces in a load balancing group.

active-count.description: Number of active member interfaces in a load balancing group.

member-infos.description: List of interface information of load balancing group.

member-info.description: Statistics of interface name of load balancing group member.

delay-time.description: Delay time after which an interface responds to user login requests.

up-down-times.description: Number of times that a member interface alternates between up and down.

is-chasten.description: Penalty flag. A punished interface is not used for load balancing. The default penalty time is 5 minutes. After 5 minutes, the interface is available for load balancing again.

first-up-down-time.description: Time when an interface goes up or down for the first time if the penalty flag is not set, or penalty time if the penalty flag is set.

backup-group.description: Configure one vBRAS-UP's interface and another vBRAS-UP's interface as a hot backup group on a vBRAS-CP. If the backup groups bound to a backup policy template share a remote four-dimensional interface pool, a bound remote four-dimensional interface cannot be used by other backup groups, regardless of the type of the backup policy template. The UPIDs of the interfaces configured for the backup groups bound to a backup policy template must be bound to the same UP backup group. The primary backup interface and secondary backup interface in a backup group must have dufferebt UPIDs. In the same policy template, if the backup groups are bound to sub-interfaces, the primary backup interfaces of the backup groups must have the same UPID, and the secondary backup interfaces of the backup groups must have the same UPID.

backup-group.description: Configure one vBRAS-UP's interface and another vBRAS-UP's interface as a hot backup group on a vBRAS-CP. If the backup groups bound to a backup policy template share a remote four-dimensional interface pool, a bound remote four-dimensional interface cannot be used by other backup groups, regardless of the type of the backup policy template. The UPIDs of the interfaces configured for the backup groups bound to a backup policy template must be bound to the same UP backup group. The primary backup interface and secondary backup interface in a backup group must have dufferebt UPIDs. In the same policy template, if the backup groups are bound to sub-interfaces, the primary backup interfaces of the backup groups must have the same UPID, and the secondary backup interfaces of the backup groups must have the same UPID.

ppp-chastens.description: List of restricts the number of connection requests from a PPP user.

ppp-chasten.description: Configure the number of connection requests from a PPP user.

quick-offline.description: Enable/disable specifies the maximum number of times that a PPP user can go offline immediately after going online during a specific time period. If a large number of users go offline immediately after going online on a live network, the CPU is overloaded or the RADIUS server may go Down. After you specify quickoffline, PPP user accounts are frozen for blocking-period seconds if the PPP users go offline immediately after going online for request-sessions times during request-period seconds.

chasten.description: Restricts the number of connection requests from a PPP user is restricted based on MAC addresses.

option105.description: Restricts the number of connection requests from a PPP user based on the Option 105 information, it can not support with one-to-many mappings between one MAC address and multiple PPP sessions at the same time.

padi-discard.description: Enable/disable specifies that the packets of the users whose accounts are frozen are discarded in the PPPoE active discovery initiation (PADI) phase. By default, the packets of the users whose accounts are frozen are discarded in the PPPoE active discovery request (PADR) phase.

multi-sessions-per-mac.description: Enable/disable restricts the number of PPP connection requests based on the MAC address in scenarios in which one-to-many mappings between one MAC address and multiple PPP sessions are configured.

request-sessions.description: Specifies the number of PPP connection requests.

request-period.description: Specifies the period for sending PPP connection requests in seconds.

block-period.description: Specifies the period when a PPP connection request is blocked in seconds.

ppp-echo-slow-acl.description: Configure PPP slow reply for PPP echo packets with a specified MAC address.

slot-warning-value.description: Sets an alarm threshold for PPP users allowed to access an interface board. By default, the alarm threshold for PPP users allowed to access an interface board is 100.

entire-warning-value.description: Sets an alarm threshold for PPP users allowed to access the entire. By default, the alarm threshold for PPP users allowed to access the entire is 100.

bgp-over-pppoe-enable.description: Configure BGP route forwarding between a CPE and BRAS.

over-pppoe-enable.description: Enable/disable BGP route forwarding between a CPE and BRAS.

name-check.description: Enable/disable the device to check whether a login request from a PPPopE user contains a user name and to deny the request if it does not contain a user name.

gateway-loopback.description: Enable/disable a loopback address as the preferentially used gateway address for PPPoE users who receive IP addresses from the RADIUS server.

offline-standardize.description: Enable/disable the conversion of the PPPoE user offline reason.

pppoe-rui-session-segment.description: Configure PPPoE RUI remote-mac session-id segment.

ppp-vlan-subinterface.description: Configure the Statistics of PPP qinq Sub Interface.

pppoe-option82-sub-option.description: Configure enable a device to encapsulate sub-options into the Option 82 field of DHCP Discover messages to be sent to the DHCP server in scenarios where IP addresses are assigned to PPPoE users from a remote address pool.

option82-sub-option-enable.description: Enable/disable whether a device is enabled to encapsulate sub-options into the Option 82 field of DHCP Discover messages to be sent to the DHCP server in scenarios where IP addresses are assigned to PPPoE users from a remote address pool.

pppoe-server.description: Configure information about the PPPoE server.

ncp-limit-enable.description: Enable/disable whether the function to limit the number of times for interface boards to receive IPCP negotiation packets is enabled. 0: The function is not enabled. 1: The function is enabled.

same-user-forbid-flag.description: Enable/disable allow access of users with same MAC address or not.

padt-delay-flag.description: Enable/disable whether PADT packets of PPPoE users are delayed to be sent.

remote-mac-max-session-number.description: Maximum number of sessions that can be negotiated by the remote MAC address.

check-location.description: Enable/disable users with the same location information are not allowed to go online after the check-location is configured. When a new user goes online at the same location, the old user is forced to go offline.

padi-mac-check.description: Enable/disable a device to check MAC address conflicts when it processes PADI packets.

max-pay-load-flag.description: Enable/disable whether the MRU is negotiated.
